body: The roxygen style generator is checked in #296

@tqchen I have dealt with the commit merge issue, and using `_init_iter()` in `_init_eval_iter()`. I also modified `_init_iter()`, adding extra checks. Hope my modification to the code is ok. I have tested in various cases using `fit()` and `predict()`, and the results are normal.

To make sure I didn't do anything unexpected, I will briefly list what I did to my fork and this PR:
1. Make a fork and clone a local copy.
2. Add `_init_eval_iter()` and then docstring. (2 commits)
3. Try to rebase the last 2 commits. Fail to push to Github.
4. Use `pull` to update the local copy and push again. Succeed.
5. Push the "Update branch" bottom on this PR page. (5 commits appear!)
6. Fail to rebase in various ways. Use `git reset --hard HEAD~3`.
7. Edit `model.py` as @tqchen and @antinucleon suggested.
8. Test modified code in various cases.
9. `git add -A` and `git commit -m "<Message...>"`.
10. Fail to `push` so use `git push --force`.
11. Wait for the travis to finish.

It seems that neither of `git reset --hard` and `git push --force` is suggested, and I am not sure whether or not my operation will have some unexpected effect.

If there are any problems with my code, I will try to fix it soon.

BTW, I think the right thing to do is that I wait for this PR to be done before I use `pull` or "Update branch" to keep my fork synced and don't push other commits (or I will need to start a new branch). And after the PR is done, I can merge the corresponding branch with, say, a "master" branch. Am I right?

@II-Matto It is fine to git push --force to your own fork, As long as the changes are only yours. Thanks Please update the PR to add your name to  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md and I will merge it in

Since this is the first time I participate in an open source projects, what I really wanted to know, at the very beginning, is the right operations and steps. I had no idea what I needed to know at first, and even didn't know what to search for. After this pull request was finished, I did some googling, and found this blog post very useful: https://gun.io/blog/how-to-github-fork-branch-and-pull-request/ (Unfortunately, this seems to be outiside GFW. A Bing cached page may help in some cases.).

[This blog post](https://gun.io/blog/how-to-github-fork-branch-and-pull-request/) lists the necessary steps (with some of my personal addition):
1. **Check out the "Network" graph** , e.g. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/network. It is also necessary to check out existing issues and pull requests.
2. **Open an issue for discussion**.
3. **Make a fork**. See https://help.github.com/articles/fork-a-repo/.
4. **Clone the fork** to get a local working copy.
5. **Add upstream** to get synced with the original repository.
6. **Setup a development branch**. I guess it is a good idea to use a new branch for each new feature or fix, since "you can only have one Pull Request per branch".
7. **Do the development**. Maybe you will commit crazily to the development branch. Also, don't forget to discuss with others.
8 **Squash commits**, i.e. merge small and unnecessary commit pieces into larger and meaningful commits.
9. **Submit a Pull Request (PR)**, discuss, fix problems, etc. Work with other contributors to finally make a good patch.
10. Wait for the owner to merge or reject the PR.
11. Done!
12. Maybe merge the development branch to the forked master branch, and start new branch for new features.

I am not sure whether new commits will keep appearing in a pull request after it is merged, or merging the development branch with the forked master branch will ever effect the corresponding pull request.

If you like to share your experience and contribute to the  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/doc/contribute.md  to make others to get started more easily

It is more than welcomed :) Thanks for the contribution
@tqchen I will do that after I perform some experiments to confirm the right thing to do. Thanks the team for making such a good open source project!
Might due to module unloading and de-allocation of things after module destruction. I am not sure exactly what it could be though.

Hmm... that could be possible. But even if I disabled all calls to `MX***Free` destructors, I still get the same error. Is there anything else that should be called other than `MXNotifyShutdown` to properly shutdown everything?
No, there is no need to call other things, MXNotifyShutdown is only a hint for the engine, which is also not needed, if the thing is reproducible , can you check where the lock exactly is?
Just a remainder: this is not a standard package, vignettes might not be generated correctly during installing.
No we are generating and host it online here. @thirdwing I think we can also make it a "standard one" by using `make Rpack` trick of xgboost

Further commenting out the function body at `resource.cc:160`, then the error disappeared.

Seems was due to engine singleton get deleted before the resource manager. Which is not suppose to be so due to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/resource.cc#L39 

We had a way to get the shared pointer from engine, to ensure it is always deleted after the resource manager.

Can you check if the destructor of engine happens before or after this destructor ?

It is here
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/engine/threaded_engine_perdevice.cc#L47

Here are some more background. The singleton pattern in C++ can have potential problem, especially in terms of destructing order.

For example, in this example, if engine singleton get destructed before resource manager singleton, then this can lead to an undefined behavior of Engine::Get()

To prevent that, the current implementation place the singleton in a shared pointer, and allow resource manager to get reference of that shared ptr, so engine won't get destructed before resource manager did

Yes, thanks for the backgrounds. But it seems the destructor of the engine is **not** called before the destructor of the resource manager. I inserted `printf` at the front of both destructors. The destructor `~ResourceManagerImpl()` is being called, but I did not see the destructor `~ThreadedEnginePerDevice()` printed yet.
And I could still print out non-NULL the address of the `Engine` object in front of the resource manager destructor. So it seems at least the `shared_ptr` holding the engine has not reset yet.
Currently I traced it to this line, trying to allocate new operator: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/engine/threaded_engine.cc#L190

OK, the actually error on mutex happens at this line:
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/common/object_pool.h#L121
OK, this was another singleton destructing problem. Thanks to point this out

This can be fixed by the shared pointer trick and let the engine hold the ref to the obj pool, @pluskid do you want to make a PR on this?

Also cc @hotpxl  who was original author of this code
Thanks, this is merged

This was rooted deeply into OpenCL support for mxnet. It is hard for short term, mainly due to the lack of support of template programming in current opencl, which makes it hard for https://github.com/dmlc/mshadow to compile on OpenCL.

There is a future proposal of enhancing opencl with c++(11) features. I think things will become more natural after that
Awesome, thank you

Seems was due to opencv installation problem, guess was because opencv was compiled under LLVM toolchain. I guess LLVM toolchain might be better for us.

You can simply disable openmp, as it is only used for parallel data loading. This only matters when you have two or more TitanX and GPU speed outruns the data loading.

I think we like to have the zip version, so advanced user can put things wherever they like and setup path manually. And a additional setup script in the zip to help user to install things when they donnot know what to do

Thanks for contribution, this is merged. I have added your name to https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md Please feel free to push future changes to your info, and other things you like to add

@tqchen Just re-installed opencv from brew and confirmed:

```
Warning: homebrew/science/opencv dependency gcc was built with a different C++ standard
library (libstdc++ from clang). This may cause problems at runtime.
```

Looks like we should stay with clang LLVM for OSX.

there are two options:
- use the system installed clang and get opencv from brew/port
- use an installed gcc and then build opencv from source using gcc (takes a few minutes...)
Looks like the first choice is the most common, and installing OpenCV from brew is much easier, so I will stay for the first choice for making pip installation.

`opencv.pc` is usually installed to `$PREFIX/lib/pkgconfig`. For example, it might be `/usr/lib/pkgconfig`, `/usr/local/lib/pkgconfig`. Or if you compile openCV and install it locally at any prefix you specified, you might find it at `prefix/lib/pkgconfig`.

If there is no opencv.pc You can also do it by changing https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L46

``pkg-config --cflags opencv`` to `-I/path/to/opencv/include`

``pkg-config --libs opencv`` to `-L/path/to/opencv/libs`

@thirdwing The dll might be VS 2013 runtime. The exception handling mechanism should be fine, as we catch most exceptions in the libmxnet.dll and return a 0 in the C API. So exception would not cross the dll boundary
After switching to `sjlj`, we don't need to include `libgcc_seh.dll`.

libgcc_seh.dll is the dependency introduced by openblas.

HONG Chuntao
System Research Group
Microsoft Research Asia
So you are using precompiled openblas? It will be better if you can compile it using sjlj. But it doesn't matter, I think.

For reference [Mocha.jl](https://github.com/pluskid/Mocha.jl) also used (with, height, channel, num) layout. 

This may also mean for all the shape related parameters, like stride, kernel size, should also follow a (width, height) convention, and we need to do conversion when pass things into the backend.
fixed by #278
+1 for 2. a typo: reserving -> reversing
I vote for 2 to not confuse other R users.
i'm not a R user, but i'm thinking in the column major when using matlab. i'll probably switch to julia later, mxnet.jl quite makes sense for me

Though not R dev, I vote for 2. It is more natural for R/Julia (and potentially matlab) users to think in that way. And it cause less confusion when working with language's native Array types. 

There is caveat though: the API needs to be careful when passing parameters back to libmxnet. Currently what MXNet.jl does is to assume all parameters of type `Tuple{N,Int}` should be shape, and it gets reversed before dumping into string (primarily when constructing new `Symbol` or `DataIter`). The assumption is definitely not true but at least up to now seems valid. If we are to adopt this convention for both R and Julia binding, we might need to extend the underlying libmxnet API a bit to at least allow the frontend to know which parameter corresponds to a _shape_ parameter that should be reversed.

As far as I know, very very few people are using R for image processing. I will switch to other tools for images. 

Actually no **traditional** or **natural** way in R for this problem. Keeping consistent with other tools will be a better solution.

Here are some potential problem in doing 2(which we need to address), 
- The json format did not involve shape conversion, this means interpretation json shape should be reversed in native bindings.
- The code for building symbols will not be directly copy-pastable between python and R/julia with non rectangle shapes (this is a less problem)

One remaining question for you guys, when doing simple MLP training, is it natural to use 
features x examples in R/Julia as opposed to examples x features?
Since going column major means we adopt nfeature x nexamples in the input layout. We can still potentially do a conversion manually though.

@tqchen I prefer feature x examples in Julia. This is just a personal preference. I think for matrices, it is not really a problem. But when each data point has higher order dimension, it could get quite confusing if one is not following the native convention in the language. For example, for MNIST batch tensor, shape (28,28,1,100) clearly makes sense in Julia because each data point (28,28,1,1) is a continuous piece of memory.
if doing doing sgd, most people (should) use the format features x example (in matlab). but i need to say, in most cases, example x feature is the default way...

Also if we want to support HDF5 (supported by Caffe, Torch, Mocha.jl, pylearn2, etc, and with standard libraries to read/write from Matlab,numpy,Julia,etc.), the basic data types in HDF5 are general tensors, the same file when loading from Python and Julia, will reads to "reversed" shape, for the same reason.

It is clear we will go for option 2, (use the default memory layout). 

The question remains whether support example x feature vs feature x example in simple MLP case. I think we are fine as long as we are consistent. Most classifier packages seems still follows example x features because this is what will be loaded from csv file. So maybe we need to do a bit smart conversion for such case.

We could detect which dimension is samples by looking at the labels. But that would fail for some special cases, e.g. when multi-dimension regression and Y has the same number of dimensions as the input. Maybe "a clear documentation and a warning when detected that the user might be supplying the transpose of X" is better than trying to figure out automatically all the situations?
Yes, I agree for a warning solution
It is here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/make/osx.mk

Thanks,

Now, I'm in "R Package Installation", error shows:

Jeff-2:mxnet urAD_Jeff$ R CMD INSTALL R-package
-bash: R: command not found

How to fix it?

@tqchen now we have both CPU and GPU version of binary distribution on Windows. I also wrote a script that will setup the environmental variables (MXNET_HOME and PATH). 

Due to dynamic linkage of cuda runtime, the size of GPU version is huge. Don't know if we can trim it down further.

The Caffe / Mocha.jl way of handling this is to allow "multiple dimensions" in the softmax loss layer. For example, the label could be (using Python's row-based ordering) `N-by-1-by-P`, while the predictions will be `N-by-K-by-P` where `N` is number of samples in mini-batch, `K` is number of classes, `P` could be interpreted as number of positions / pixels. In general, the prediction could be any ND tensor, and label will be a tensor with corresponding shape, except one of the dimension is a singleton dimension (of size 1). For example, pixel-wise prediction would be
- Label: `N-by-1-by-H-by-W`
- Prediction: `N-by-K-by-H-by-W`

In terms of image segmentation, I think this [CRF-as-RNN Caffe Code](https://github.com/torrvision/crfasrnn) might be a very nice one to incorporate into MXNet and serving as a cool demo. I might consider doing it when I squeeze out some time but it seems not very recently. So @tornadomeet if you are working in segmentation you could probably add this.

BTW: just as a side comment since our current `Softmax` operator is being discussed. It is a bit confusing at first when I was using the `Softmax` operator. The `forward` operation behave exactly like a softmax, but in the backward operation, it becomes a _softmax with multiclass logistic loss_. I guess this might be due to efficiency consideration or code re-use, but it leads to some inconvenience / inconsistency.
- The `Softmax` operator needs both `data` and `label` as arguments, though if people only do prediction, only the `data` is needed.
- There is no objective function value of the logistic loss computed. Though it does not really affect the learning, and especially we are running for a fixed number of iterations, we do not need to rely on it for stop condition, either. But the correct objective function value serves important role for debugging. For example, when researcher are writing their own layers or new optimizers, looking at how the objective function changing at a finer scale might be very helpful for testing whether it is implemented correctly, and if not where might be some issues.
- People might need to use some other losses on top of the `Softmax` probabilistic output. Caffe / Mocha.jl currently have a `Softmax` layer that does just softmax, and then a `SoftmaxLoss` layer which combines softmax and logistic loss. I think this might be a viable alternative way.

The followings are just some minor thoughts on the general design:
- Currently the `label` arguments for `Softmax` is an `implicit` arguments. If I understand correctly, there is no way to (like `data`) construct a `Variable` as the `label` and compose them like this

```
data = mx.symbol.Variable('data-foo')
label = mx.symbol.Variable('label-foo')
net = mx.symbol.Softmax(data=data, label=label, name='out')
```

This essentially allows us to _rename_ the label variable to whatever we want, as in the `data` case. Then when the user construct `DataIter`, he/she can specify what names (`data-foo` and `label-foo` in this case) the `DataIter` is providing (this is also the current design used in MXNet.jl). So when we train the network with this `DataIter` we actually knows which ones are data which ones are labels. The current way (automatically deciding based on a `data` or `label` postfix) is nice, but it might get confused to figure out the exact correspondence in multiple-input multiple-output case (RNN case, not image segmentation case). 
- Since the loss functions are only used during training, we might use the following convention: when defining the architecture, the user only defines the network up to the output layer. A loss layer is provided when the user calls `fit`, and the network is composed with the loss criterion on the fly. But otherwise, the loss is not a part of the architecture and the semantic for doing `predict` with the network is clearer. For example, [Lasagne](http://lasagne.readthedocs.org/en/latest/), a light-weighted framework based on Theano has this design.
I will test the R package using your dll right now.
If necessary, the numpy.transpose function could be called. It is general enough to permute dimensions of a high order tensor.
